awd_titl_txt: Implementation of an Industry-Recognized Credentialing System for Biotechnicians
awd_abstract_narration:
The ATE program supports biotechnology technician education programs that partner with industry to ensure the education of a skilled bioscience technical workforce. Yet, there remains a gap between educational preparation and industry’s recognition of potential workers who have completed two-year biotechnology programs. Over the next ten years, reports predict that life science companies will have an increased demand for skilled technical workers, and that filling these positions will be difficult.  Thus, preparation of sufficient biotechnicians represents a significant need for the biological economy and related sectors. This project aims to bridge the gap between education and industry through an industry-recognized biotechnician credentialing system. Recently, the Bioscience Industry has identified the Biotechnician Assistant Credentialing Exam (BACE) as an effective tool to certify student capabilities.  This exam is already used in six states and the District of Columbia, thus increasing its potential to become the industry-recognized credentialing system for entry-level biotechnicians. This project will pilot the BACE system in five additional states, build consortia of industry and education stakeholders, and disseminate BACE broadly through InnovATEBIO (an NSF ATE Center of Excellence) and the Consortium for Advanced Manufacturing of Cell-based Therapies (an Advanced Technical Education Coordination Network). A nationwide industry-recognized credentialing system will give students a portable credential that is recognized across the nation, thus helping to address the workforce gap in the life science industry. This credentialing model may also inform credentialing approaches for other areas of technician education.

The BACE credential was developed through engagement of educators with industry and industry representatives.  This partnership continues to evaluate the credential to ensure that it meets changing industry needs. This project intends to expand the number of states using the BACE by adding Georgia, Washington, California, Texas, and Nebraska.  To this end, it will set up state task forces comprised of industry professionals, educational leaders, and government representatives.  Each task force will examine the use and sustainability of BACE in their state. Testing sites will be established in each state, and the sites will provide faculty and teachers with professional development to understand the BACE, so they can support students’ exam preparation. The project will leverage the extensive networks of InnovATEBIO and the Consortium for Advanced Manufacturing of Cell-based Therapies to disseminate the BACE credential, and also disseminate it through national and state industry associations, district-level industry advisory boards, boards of education, technical educators, and government officials. A nationally recognized credential has strong potential to improve the transition from two-year college technician education programs to employment in the biotechnology industry. This result would not only serve the industry, but also serve the emerging workforce by identifying skillsets in demand across the country. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation’s economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Bridging the gap between education and industry can be accomplished using an industry-recognized credentialing system, as it provides a clear roadmap of industry-defined standards to be incorporated into courses and programs, which in turn can be validated through an ISO 17024 compliant credentialing organization. Numerous attempts have been made to establish an effective credentialing system for the bioscience industry, however one that has earned widespread acceptance is the Biotechnology Aptitude and Competency Exam (BACE), an industry-recognized exam offered by UF Biotility. Built from an industry DACUM analysis, the exam framework is designed to accurately assess core skills and knowledge sets including competencies foundational to technician level positions. Reviewed and updated annually with oversight from a national advisory board, the BACE remains current to industry needs nationwide. In the spring of 2021, the National Science Foundation Advanced Technological Education (NSF ATE) program funded a project called “Implementation of an Industry-Recognized Credentialing System (IRCS).” Its purpose was to address the need for an industry-supported, nationally recognized credential by disseminating the successful BACE credentialing model from Florida.

Biotechnology and its associated industries represent an application of biology to make products which improve lives. Hence, the principal discipline of biology finds its practical application through biotechnology. Unlike other disciplines such as engineering or medicine, the practice of biotechnology is much less evident to the general public. Careers in this field are equally nebulous. The IRCS project has had a direct impact on the biotechnology discipline by revealing the practical application of biology and its associated career paths to a much wider audience. The expansion of an industry-recognized BACE credential brings a prepared and validated workforce to the industry. This provides a readily identifiable career much in the same way as professional engineers, nurses, and doctors do for their industries.

The major activities accomplished under the IRCS grant were to establish task forces in Georgia, Texas, Nebraska, California, and Washington, the BACE exam was piloted in all 5 states, and the value of BACE was communicated through both InnovATEBIO and professional development opportunities for teachers.  Objectives were met and exceeded in the process of accomplishing all of the grant’s goals. Stakeholders were identified in each state and task forces were built with designated state coordinators. Regular meetings were held which infused BACE into each state’s biotech ecosystem. Testing sites were identified, site administrators trained, candidates tested, and credentials earned. BACE attributes were communicated extensively through conference attendance, presentations, published endorsements, InnovATEBIO meetings, workshops, forums, and an international video release.

Grant-funded testing was administered to 900 candidates of which 440 earned BACE credentials. Large industry partners listed BACE as a preferred hiring credential. Thirty-two testing sites were established in the 5 states, twice the number targeted. Well over 100 teachers participated in Industrial Biotechnology Teacher Experience (IBTE) teacher training and sat for the BACE exams themselves enabling effective communication with their students about industry expectations and BACE. The number of participating states grew dramatically from 7 to 32 participating states during the grant period. As a testament to the effectiveness of the grant accomplishments, it concluded with participation of not only the five (5) NSF grant participating states, but also sixteen (16) states plus the District of Columbia that have adopted the BACE, and an additional sixteen (16) states which are using the BACE for a grand total of 32 states. This is a significant growth and application of the BACE credential in the US. Sustainability consists of continued BACE evaluation by nationwide industry representation on the advisory board, delivery through the extensive testing network throughout the country, and persistent development and roll out of industry-driven credentialing through the Biotility credentialing system.
